item.title: The Rise of Classic Home Computers | Commodore, Atari, Apple, TI & Tandy
item.description:
Before consoles dominated the living room and before personal computers became household appliances, owning a computer at home felt like stepping into the future.
In the late 1970s through the 1980s and early 1990s, classic home computers began appearing on desks, kitchen tables, and bedrooms around the world. These machines weren‚Äôt just for games, they were tools for learning, experimenting, programming, and discovering how technology really worked.
This video explores some of the most influential classic home computer platforms, including systems from Commodore, Atari, Apple, Texas Instruments, Tandy, and others that helped define early home computing.
This is not an exhaustive list, the home computer market was massive and constantly evolving, but it is a look at the machines that mattered most, the ones many of us grew up with, learned on, and still remember today.
From cassette tapes and floppy disks to command lines and BASIC programming, these computers laid the groundwork for the digital world we now take for granted.
If you enjoy retro tech, classic computing, and gaming history, consider liking, commenting, and subscribing to help keep this history alive.
üñ•Ô∏è RetroGamer Gen X- documenting the technology we grew up with.

item.description: A guide to controlling Claude Code running on your laptop from your phone over SSH using Termius, Tailscale, and tmux.

item.title: Adaptec RAID cards are junk
item.description: From time to time, people would complain about this deleted driver and argue that other OSs were superior because they supported this bad hardware (usually without the fixes in the drivers that were needed). This story was originally posted on one of the OpenBSD mail lists in three installments -- it wasn't intended to be three installments, but the story kept getting better/worse as time went on.

item.title: davidbau.com In Defense of Curiosity
item.description: At the NeurIPS Mechanistic Interpretability Workshop, I was asked to give an opinion on Neel Nanda's recent blog post on "pragmatic interpretability." I chose to respond by recounting the story of Venetian glassmaking.

item.title: Why Custom Evals Matter for Production LLMs
item.description: Generic benchmarks measure breadth across many tasks. Your application needs depth on one specific task. This is why custom evals matter for production LLMs.

For a complete introduction to Lua programming, see the book Programming in Lua.
